sutra:
ॐ पूर्णमदः पूर्णमिदं पूर्णात् पूर्णमुदच्यते।

पूर्णस्य पूर्णमादाय पूर्णमेवावशिष्यते॥

ॐ शान्तिः शान्तिः शान्तिः॥
transliteration_kn:
ಓಂ | ಪೂರ್ಣಮದಃ ಪೂರ್ಣಮಿದಂ ಪೂರ್ಣಾತ್ಪೂರ್ಣಮುದಚ್ಯತೇ ।
ಪೂರ್ಣಸ್ಯ ಪೂರ್ಣಮಾದಾಯ ಪೂರ್ಣಮೇವಾವಶಿಷ್ಯತೇ ॥

ಓಂ. ಶಾಂತಿ! ಶಾಂತಿ!! ಶಾಂತಿ!!!
transliteration_hi:
ॐ पूर्णमदः पूर्णमिदं पूर्णात् पूर्णमुदच्यते।

पूर्णस्य पूर्णमादाय पूर्णमेवावशिष्यते॥

ॐ शान्तिः शान्तिः शान्तिः॥
transliteration_en:
oṃ pūrṇamadaḥ pūrṇamidaṃ pūrṇātpūrṇamudacyate |

pūrṇasya pūrṇamādāya pūrṇamevāvaśiṣyate ||

oṃ śāntiḥ | śāntiḥ | śāntiḥ ||
meaning_en: That is complete; this is complete. From completeness emerges completeness. When completeness is taken from completeness, completeness still remains.
meaning_kn: ಅದು ಪೂರ್ಣವಾಗಿರುತ್ತದೆ, ಇದು ಪೂರ್ಣವಾಗಿರುತ್ತದೆ. ಪೂರ್ಣದಿಂದ ಪೂರ್ಣವು ಉದ್ಭವಿಸುತ್ತದೆ. ಪೂರ್ಣದಿಂದ ಪೂರ್ಣವನ್ನು ತೆಗೆದುಹಾಕಿದರೂ, ಉಳಿದುದೂ ಪೂರ್ಣವಾಗಿರುತ್ತದೆ. ಓಂ ಶಾಂತಿಃ ಶಾಂತಿಃ ಶಾಂತಿಃ॥
tellmemore_en_adv: This mantra reinforces the teachings of Advaita Vedanta by illustrating the infinite nature of both the supreme, unmanifested Brahman and the manifested, conditioned Brahman. It teaches that the universe, with all its diverse forms, emerges from the infinite Brahman, retaining its inherent infinitude. Through the knowledge of this true nature, one realizes that the conditioned Brahman (the manifested world) is essentially the same as the supreme Brahman. This realization dissolves the illusion of separateness, revealing the underlying unity of all existence. By understanding the infinite nature of both the source and the manifestation, one attains the vision of oneness, which is central to Advaita philosophy. The repeated invocation of peace signifies the ultimate tranquility and liberation that come with this profound realization.
tellmemore_en_dva: In Dvaita philosophy, which maintains a dualistic understanding of reality, this mantra underscores the distinct and complete nature of both the Supreme Being (Vishnu or Brahman) and the individual souls (jivas). According to Dvaita, "That" (Adah) refers to the Supreme Brahman, who is perfect and complete in itself. "This" (Idam) refers to the individual soul, which is also complete in its essence. The mantra illustrates that the Supreme Brahman is the source of all creation and remains unchanged and complete even after the creation process. The individual soul, though a part of creation, retains its distinct completeness derived from the Supreme. Despite the infinite process of creation, Brahman’s infinitude remains undiminished, highlighting the eternal, unchanging nature of God. The invocation of peace (Shanti) three times at the end signifies peace in the physical, mental, and spiritual realms, acknowledging the overarching completeness and tranquility of the divine.
tellmemore_en_vis:
The mantra "Om Purnamadah Purnamidam" emphasizes the completeness and fullness of both the ultimate reality (Brahman) and the manifested world. According to Vishishtadvaita, Brahman, with its infinite attributes and auspicious qualities, pervades everything, and this world is a manifestation of Brahman’s glory.

"That (other world) is full with the Veda" signifies that the spiritual realm is complete and perfect, filled with divine knowledge and truth as embodied in the Vedas. "This (world) is full with the Veda" implies that even the physical world is permeated with the divine knowledge and presence of Brahman.

The phrase "That which fills is more celebrated than the world that is filled" highlights the supremacy of Brahman, the source of all creation and existence. The manifested world, though full and complete in itself, derives its completeness from Brahman.

When the "Vyahrithi," or the agent of filling, is withdrawn from the world, what remains is the "Om Karatmaka Vastu," the ultimate reality characterized by Om, which is Brahman. This signifies the inherent and unchanging nature of Brahman, even when the dynamic aspects of creation and sustenance are set aside.

In essence, this mantra encapsulates the belief that Brahman is both immanent and transcendent, pervading all of existence while remaining beyond it. This fullness is the ultimate reality that remains constant, highlighting the non-dual yet multifaceted nature of Brahman as understood in Vishishtadvaita.

sutra:
ॐ ई॒शा वा॒स्य॑मि॒द सर्वं॒ यत्किं च॒ जग॑त्यां॒ जग॑त् ।

तेन॑ त्य॒क्तेन॑ भुञ्जीथा॒ मा गृ॑धः॒ कस्य॑ स्वि॒द्धन॑म् ॥१॥
transliteration_kn:
ಈಶಾವಾಸ್ಯಮಿದಂ ಸರ್ವಂ ಯತ್ಕಿಂಚ ಜಗತ್ಯಾಂ ಜಗತ್ ।
ತೇನ ತ್ಯಕ್ತೇನ ಭುಂಜೀಥಾ ಮಾ ಗೃಧಃ ಕಸ್ಯ ಸ್ವಿದ್ಧನಮ್ ॥ 1 ॥
transliteration_hi: ॐ ईशा वास्यमिदꣳ सर्वं यत्किं च जगत्यां जगत् । तेन त्यक्तेन भुञ्जीथा मा गृधः कस्य स्विद्धनम् ॥ १॥
transliteration_en:
īśā vāsyam idaṃ sarvaṃ yat kiñca jagatyāṃ jagat |

tena tyaktena bhuñjīthā mā gṛdhaḥ kasya sviddhanam || 1 ||
meaning_en: Om. This entire universe, including all that moves and does not move, is pervaded by the Divine. Protect yourself through renunciation and contentment; do not covet wealth, for whose is wealth truly?
meaning_hi: जगत् में जो कुछ स्थावर-जंगम संसार है वह सब ईश्वरके द्वारा आच्छादनीय है [ अर्थात् उसे भगवत्स्वरूप अनुभव करना चाहिये ] | उसके त्याग-भावसे तू अपना पालन कर; किसीके धनकी इच्छा न कर ॥ १ ॥
meaning_kn: ಜಗತ್ತಿನಲ್ಲಿ (ಸ್ಥಾವರ) ಜಂಗಮಾತ್ಮಕವಾದದ್ದು ಏನೇನಿದೆಯೋ ಅದೆಲ್ಲವೂ ಈಶನಿಂದ ಮುಚ್ಚಲ್ಪಡತಕ್ಕದ್ದು. ಆದ್ದರಿಂದ ತ್ಯಾಗದಿಂದ ಕಾಪಾಡಿಕೊ: ಯಾರ ಧನವನ್ನೂ ಬಯಸಬೇಡ.
tellmemore_en_adv:
This entire universe, including everything that moves and everything that doesn't, is covered by the Divine. Understanding this Divine presence is important because it is our true nature. To live a peaceful and content life, we need to let go of our attachment to material possessions and desires. The core principle of Advaita philosophy is realizing that "I am the inner Self of all beings."

This realization removes the illusion of separateness and brings a sense of unity with everything. Wealth and material possessions are not truly owned by anyone because everything is part of the Divine. Therefore, we should live contentedly, recognizing the unity of all existence.

By giving up the desire for wealth and embracing the idea that everything is a part of the Divine, we can lead a life of peace and spiritual growth. This understanding opens the path to spiritual development and brings us eternal happiness and peace.
tellmemore_en_dva:
God is present everywhere, and everything in the universe depends on Him. God is the one who makes everything function, and without Him, nothing can exist or work. He is the only independent entity, while everything else, including the material world and living beings, rely on Him.

For spiritual growth, it is crucial to eliminate greed. Since everything we have is given by God, we should be content with what He provides. Greed and the desire for more are futile because all things and beings are under God's control. Realizing God's omnipresence and His role as the sustainer of the universe helps us reduce our greed and live a life of contentment.

This understanding leads to recognizing the unity of all existence and our dependence on the Divine. By accepting that everything belongs to God, we can focus on spiritual growth and inner peace.
tellmemore_en_vis:
God, specifically Sriman Narayana, pervades everything in the universe. This includes both living (sentient) and non-living (insentient) entities. God is distinct from these entities but exists within them as their innermost self. Without God's presence and guidance, nothing can function. He alone is truly independent, and all other things depend on Him.

The term "vasyam" signifies that God dwells in everything, everywhere, as the inner self. This verse teaches us to enjoy life with a sense of detachment and without greed. Greed is unnecessary because all entities and their functions are under God's control. The mantra advises us to use only what is necessary for living and spiritual practice, without any attachment. By recognizing God's omnipresence and our dependence on Him, we can live a life free from the desire for wealth and material possessions, focusing instead on spiritual growth.
tellmemore_kn_adv:
ಈ ಇಡೀ ಜಗತ್ತು, (ಚಲಿಸುವ ಮತ್ತು ಸ್ಥಿರವಾಗಿರುವ ಎರಡೂ), ದೈವದಿಂದ ಆವೃತವಾಗಿದೆ. ದೈವಿಯ ತತ್ತ್ವವನ್ನು ಅರಿತುಕೊಳ್ಳುವುದು ಮುಖ್ಯ, ಏಕೆಂದರೆ ಇದು ನಮ್ಮ ನಿಜ ಸ್ವರೂಪವಾಗಿದೆ. ತ್ಯಾಗ ಮತ್ತು ತೃಪ್ತಿಯಿಂದ ಬದುಕಲು, ಪ್ರಪಂಚದ ಭೌತಿಕ ಆಸೆಗಳನ್ನು ಮತ್ತು ಬಾಂಧವ್ಯವನ್ನು ತ್ಯಜಿಸಬೇಕು. "ನಾನು ಎಲ್ಲಾ ಜೀವಿಗಳ ಆಂತರಿಕ ಆತ್ಮ" ಎಂಬ ಸತ್ಯವನ್ನು ಅರಿತುಕೊಳ್ಳುವುದು ಅದ್ವೈತ ತತ್ವದ ಮುಖ್ಯ ಅಂಶವಾಗಿದೆ. 

ಈ ಜ್ಞಾನವು ನಮ್ಮಲ್ಲಿ ವಿಭಿನ್ನತೆಯ ಭ್ರಮೆಯನ್ನು ಕಳೆದುಹಾಕುತ್ತದೆ ಮತ್ತು ಏಕತೆಯ ಭಾವವನ್ನು ನೀಡುತ್ತದೆ. ಸಂಪತ್ತು ಮತ್ತು ಭೌತಿಕ ಆಸ್ತಿಗಳು ಯಾರಿಗೂ ಸ್ವಂತದ್ದಾಗಿಲ್ಲ, ಏಕೆಂದರೆ ಎಲ್ಲವೂ ದೈವದ ತತ್ತ್ವದ ಪ್ರದರ್ಶನ ಎಂದರೆ ತಪ್ಪಾಗದು. ಹೀಗಾಗಿ, ನಮ್ಮ ಆಂತರಿಕ ಆತ್ಮವನ್ನು ಅರಿತುಕೊಂಡು, ತೃಪ್ತಿಯ ಜೀವನವನ್ನು ನಡೆಸಬೇಕು. 

ಸಂಪತ್ತಿನ ಆಸೆಯನ್ನು ಬಿಟ್ಟು, ದೈವದ ಭಾಗವೆಂದು ಎಲ್ಲಾ ಅಸ್ತಿತ್ವವನ್ನು ಒಪ್ಪಿಕೊಂಡು, ಪ್ರಪಂಚದ ಎಲ್ಲ ಜೀವಿಗಳೊಂದಿಗೆ ಏಕತೆಯ ಭಾವವನ್ನು ಇಟ್ಟುಕೊಂಡು, ಶಾಂತಿಯುತ ಜೀವನವನ್ನು ನಡೆಸಲು ನಾವು ಪ್ರಯತ್ನಿಸಬೇಕು. 

ಈ ತತ್ತ್ವಜ್ಞಾನವು ನಮ್ಮಲ್ಲಿ ಆಧ್ಯಾತ್ಮಿಕ ಬೆಳವಣಿಗೆಯ ಮಾರ್ಗವನ್ನು ತೆರೆದು, ನಮಗೆ ಶಾಶ್ವತ ಸಂತೋಷ ಮತ್ತು ಸಮಾಧಾನವನ್ನು ತಂದುಕೊಡುತ್ತದೆ.
tellmemore_kn_dva:
ದೇವರು ಎಲ್ಲೆಡೆ ಇದ್ದಾನೆ ಮತ್ತು ಎಲ್ಲವೂ ಅವನ ಮೇಲೆಯೇ ಅವಲಂಬಿತವಾಗಿದೆ ಎನ್ನುವುದನ್ನು ಈ ಮಂತ್ರವು ಸೂಚಿಸುತ್ತದೆ. ದೇವರಿಲ್ಲದೆ ಯಾವುದೂ ಅಸ್ತಿತ್ವದಲ್ಲಿರುವುದಿಲ್ಲ ಅಥವಾ ಕಾರ್ಯನಿರ್ವಹಿಸುವುದಿಲ್ಲ. ಅವನು ಮಾತ್ರ ಸ್ವತಂತ್ರನು, ಇತರ ಎಲ್ಲಾ ವಸ್ತುಗಳು ಮತ್ತು ಜೀವಿಗಳು ಅವನ ಮೇಲೆಯೇ ಅವಲಂಬಿತವಾಗಿವೆ.

ಆಧ್ಯಾತ್ಮಿಕ ಬೆಳವಣಿಗೆಗೆ, ಲೋಭವನ್ನು ತೊಡೆದುಹಾಕುವುದು ಅತ್ಯಂತ ಮುಖ್ಯ. ನಮ್ಮಲ್ಲಿರುವ ಎಲ್ಲವನ್ನೂ ದೇವರು ನೀಡಿದ್ದು, ಅವನು ಕೊಟ್ಟದ್ದರಲ್ಲಿ ತೃಪ್ತವಾಗಿರಬೇಕು. ಹೆಚ್ಚು ಬೇಕೆಂಬ ಆಸೆ ಮತ್ತು ಲೋಭ ನೆರವಾಗುವುದಿಲ್ಲ ಏಕೆಂದರೆ ಎಲ್ಲಾ ವಸ್ತುಗಳು ಮತ್ತು ಜೀವಿಗಳು ದೇವರ ನಿಯಂತ್ರಣದಲ್ಲಿವೆ. ದೇವರ ಎಲ್ಲೆಡೆ ಇರುವಿಕೆಯನ್ನು ಮತ್ತು ವಿಶ್ವದ ನಿರ್ವಹಣೆಯಲ್ಲಿ ಅವನ ಪಾತ್ರವನ್ನು ಅರಿತುಕೊಳ್ಳುವುದರಿಂದ ನಾವು ಲೋಭವನ್ನು ಕಡಿಮೆಮಾಡಬಹುದು ಮತ್ತು ತೃಪ್ತಿಯ ಜೀವನವನ್ನು ನಡೆಸಬಹುದು.

ಈ ತತ್ತ್ವಜ್ಞಾನವು ಎಲ್ಲಾ ಅಸ್ತಿತ್ವದ ಏಕತೆಯನ್ನು ಮತ್ತು ದೈವದ ಮೇಲಿನ ನಮ್ಮ ಅವಲಂಬನೆಯನ್ನು ಅರಿಯಲು ಸಹಾಯ ಮಾಡುತ್ತದೆ. ಎಲ್ಲವೂ ದೇವರ ಆಸ್ತಿಯೆಂದು ಒಪ್ಪಿಕೊಂಡು, ನಾವು ಆಧ್ಯಾತ್ಮಿಕ ಬೆಳವಣಿಗೆಯ ಮೇಲೆ ಮತ್ತು ಆಂತರಿಕ ಶಾಂತಿಯಲ್ಲಿ ಕೇಂದ್ರೀಕೃತವಾಗಬಹುದು.
tellmemore_kn_vis:
ದೇವರು, ವಿಶೇಷವಾಗಿ ಶ್ರೀಮನ್‌ ನಾರಾಯಣನು, ಈ ಸಮಸ್ತ ಜಗತ್ತನ್ನು ಆವೃತಗೊಂಡಿರುವನು. ಇವುಗಳಲ್ಲಿ ಚೇತನ ಮತ್ತು ಅಚೇತನ ವಸ್ತುಗಳೂ ಸೇರಿರುತ್ತವೆ. ದೇವರು ಇದರಿಂದ ವಿಭಿನ್ನನಾಗಿದ್ದು, ನಮ್ಮಗಳ ಆಂತರಿಕ ಆತ್ಮವಾಗಿ ನೆಲೆಸಿರುತ್ತಾನೆ. ದೇವರ ಪ್ರಸ್ಥಿತಿ ಮತ್ತು ಮಾರ್ಗದರ್ಶನವಿಲ್ಲದೆ ಯಾವುದೂ ಕಾರ್ಯನಿರ್ವಹಿಸಲು ಸಾಧ್ಯವಿಲ್ಲ. ಅವನು ಮಾತ್ರ ಸ್ವತಂತ್ರನು, ಇತರ ಎಲ್ಲವೂ ಅವನ ಮೇಲೆಯೇ ಅವಲಂಬಿತವಾಗಿರುತ್ತದೆ.

"ವಾಸ್ಯಂ" ಪದವು ದೇವರು ಎಲ್ಲೆಡೆ ಎಲ್ಲದರಲ್ಲೂ ಆಂತರಿಕ ಆತ್ಮವಾಗಿ ನೆಲಸಿರುವುದನ್ನು ಸೂಚಿಸುತ್ತದೆ. ಈ ಮಂತ್ರವು ತೃಪ್ತಿಯುತ ಬದುಕನ್ನು ಯಾವುದೇ ಲೋಭವಿಲ್ಲದೆ ನಡೆಸಲು ಬೋಧಿಸುತ್ತದೆ. ಇಲ್ಲಿ ಲೋಭವಾದರೋ ಅನಗತ್ಯ, ಏಕೆಂದರೆ ಎಲ್ಲಾ  ಕಾರ್ಯಗಳೂ ಸಹ ದೇವರ ನಿಯಂತ್ರಣದಲ್ಲಿರುತ್ತದೆ. ಈ ಮಂತ್ರವು ಯಾವುದೇ ಬಂಧನವಿಲ್ಲದೆ ಜೀವಿತ ಮತ್ತು ಆಧ್ಯಾತ್ಮಿಕ ಅಭ್ಯಾಸಕ್ಕೆ ಅಗತ್ಯವಾದವುಗಳನ್ನು ಮಾತ್ರ ಬಳಸುವುದನ್ನು,  ಸಲಹಿಸುತ್ತದೆ. ದೇವರ ಎಲ್ಲೆಡೆ ಇರುವಿಕೆಯು ಮತ್ತು ಅವನ ಮೇಲಿನ ನಮ್ಮ ಅವಲಂಬನೆಯನ್ನು ಅರಿತುಕೊಂಡು, ನಾವು ಧನ ಮತ್ತು ಭೌತಿಕ ಆಸ್ತಿಗಳ ಆಸೆಯನ್ನು ಬಿಟ್ಟು, ಆಧ್ಯಾತ್ಮಿಕ ಬೆಳವಣಿಗೆಯ ಮೇಲೆ ನಮ್ಮ ಮನಸನ್ನು ಕೇಂದ್ರೀಕರಿಸಿದರೆ ಒಳಿತಾಗುವುದು.

परमेश्वर परमात्मा है । वही सब जीवोंका आत्मा होकर अन्तर्यामिरूपसे सबका ईशन करता है । उस अपने स्वरूपभूत आत्मा ईशसे
सब वास्य - आच्छादन करने योग्य है ।



क्या [ आच्छादन करने योग्य है ] ? यह सब जो कुछ जगती अर्थात्. 
पृथिवीमें जगत् ( स्थावर-जंगम प्राणि- वर्ग ) हैं वह सब अपने आत्मा ईश्वर- से - अन्तर्यामिरूपसे यह सब कुछ मैं ही हूँ — ऐसा जानकर अपने परमार्थसत्यस्वरूप परमात्मासे यह सम्पूर्ण मिथ्याभूत चराचर आच्छादन करने योग्य है ।

meaning_en: Indeed, by performing one's duties, one should aspire to live here for a hundred years. For someone like you, who wishes to live this way, there is no other path to avoid the binding effects of karma.
meaning_hi: इस लोकमें कर्म करते हुए ही सौ वर्ष जीनेकी इच्छा करे । इस प्रकार मनुष्यत्वका अभिमान रखनेवाले तेरे लिये इसके सिवा और कोई मार्ग नहीं है, जिससे तुझे [ अशुभ ] कर्मका लेप न हो ॥ २ ॥
meaning_kn: ಈ ಭೂಮಿಯಲ್ಲಿ ನೂರು ವರ್ಷ ಬದುಕಬೇಕು ಎಂಬ ಆಸೆಯಿದ್ದರೆ ಕರ್ಮ ಮಾಡುತ್ತಾ ಬದುಕಬೇಕು . ಹೀಗಿರುವಾಗ, (ಎಂದು) ಮನುಷ್ಯ, ನೀವು ಬದುಕುತ್ತೀರಿ, ಕರ್ಮವು ನಿಮಗೆ ಅಂಟಿಕೊಳ್ಳದ ಬೇರೆ ಮಾರ್ಗವಿಲ್ಲ .
tellmemore_en_adv:
This verse from the Ishavasya Upanishad tells us that if a person wishes to live a long life, they should keep doing their duties and actions (karma) as prescribed by the scriptures. According to Shankara's commentary, this means following rituals and moral duties that are part of one's life. By doing so, a person can live up to a hundred years without being negatively affected by their actions. In simpler terms, it emphasizes the importance of doing good and righteous deeds throughout one’s life to avoid being trapped by the consequences of bad actions. This path is recommended for those who are not yet ready to renounce worldly life and seek knowledge of the Self (as mentioned in the previous verse).

Shankara also points out that there are two paths: one of action (karma) and one of renunciation (knowledge of the Self). For those who cannot renounce the world, performing their duties diligently is the way to live a fulfilling and unbound life.
tellmemore_en_dva: In Dvaita philosophy, the verse emphasizes the importance of performing one's duties with dedication to God. It suggests that one should aspire to live a long life, fulfilling their responsibilities as an act of worship. When duties are performed with devotion and without selfish motives, these actions do not bind the individual in the cycle of karma. Instead, they purify the mind and prepare the person for the knowledge of God. Failure to perform these prescribed duties, on the other hand, leads to sin and hinders spiritual progress. This is especially true for those who have not yet attained enlightenment, as neglecting duties can obstruct their path to liberation. Even for those who have gained knowledge and liberation, not performing duties like worship can reduce the bliss and fulfillment they experience. Thus, the verse highlights that dedicated action, done in the spirit of worship, is crucial for both spiritual progress and maintaining a pure, unattached mind.
tellmemore_en_vis: This verse emphasizes the importance of Nishkama Karma, which refers to actions performed without desire for personal gain, as essential for spiritual progress. According to Vishishtadvaita philosophy, one should desire to live a hundred years by performing their prescribed duties as an offering to God. Such selfless actions do not bind the individual because they are done with a sense of devotion and surrender to God. For someone who seeks Brahma Vidya, or knowledge of Brahman, performing duties without attachment ensures that karma does not taint them. Even if actions are done unintentionally, they do not cling to the person who has developed detachment and dedicated all actions to God. This approach helps in purifying the mind and preparing it for the realization of God. By remembering that all actions belong to God, one can transcend the cycle of birth and death and achieve liberation. The Bhagavad Gita also supports this doctrine of Karmayoga, emphasizing the importance of performing one's duties while remaining unattached to the fruits of actions.
tellmemore_kn_adv:
ಆಳುವದರಿಂದ (ಇವನಿಗೆ) ಈಶ (ಎಂದು ಹೆಸರು) ಆ ಈಶನಿಂದ. ಆಳುವವನೆಂದರೆ (ಇಲ್ಲಿ) ಪರಮೇಶ್ವರನು: ಎಲ್ಲರ ಪರಮಾತ್ಮನು. ಏಕೆಂದರೆ ಆತನೇ ಪ್ರತ್ಯಗಾತ್ಮರೂಪದಿಂದ ಎಲ್ಲಾ ಪ್ರಾಣಿಗಳ ಆತ್ಮನಾಗಿದ್ದುಕೊಂಡು ಎಲ್ಲವನ್ನೂ ಆಳುತ್ತಿರುವನು. ಆ ತನ್ನ ಸ್ವರೂಪವಾದ ಆತ್ಮನೆಂಬ ಈಶನಿಂದ ಮುಚ್ಚಬೇಕು, ಹೊದಿಸಬೇಕು. ಏನನ್ನು? ಇದೆಲ್ಲವನ್ನೂ, ಈ ಜಗತ್ತಿನಲ್ಲಿ ಅಂದರೆ ಪೃಥ್ವಿಯಲ್ಲಿ ಏನೇನು ಯಾವಯಾವದು ಸ್ಥಾವರಜಂಗಮಾತ್ಮಕವಾದದ್ದು (ಇದೆಯೋ) ಅದೆಲ್ಲವನ್ನೂ ಪ್ರತ್ಯಗಾತ್ಮರೂಪದಿಂದ ಈಶನಾಗಿರುವ ತನ್ನ ಆತ್ಮನಿಂದ ’ಇದೆಲ್ಲವೂ ನಾನೇ’ ಎಂದು ಪರಮಾರ್ಥಸತ್ಯವಾಗಿರುವ ರೂಪದ ಪರಮಾತ್ಮನಿಂದ ಸುಳ್ಳಾಗಿರುವ ಈ ಚರಾಚರೆವೆಲ್ಲವನ್ನೂ ಹೊದಿಸಬೇಕು. ಹೇಗೆ ಚಂದನ, ಅಗಿಲು ಇವುಗಳಿಗೆ ನೀರೇ ಮುಂತಾದದ್ದರಿಂದಾದ ಉಪಾಧಿಯಿಂದುಂಟಾದ ಕೆಟ್ಟ ನಾತವು ಅವುಗಳನ್ನು ತೇಯುವುದರಿಂದ (ಹುಟ್ಟುವ) ತಮ್ಮ ನಿಜವಾದ ವಾಸನೆಯಿಂದ ಮುಚ್ಚಿಹೋಗುವದೋ ಅದರಂತೆಯೇ ತನ್ನ ಆತ್ಮನಲ್ಲಿ ಅಧ್ಯಸ್ತವಾಗಿರುವ ಸ್ವಾಭಾವಿಕವಾದ ಕರ್ತೃತ್ವಭೋಕ್ತೃತ್ವ ಮುಂತಾದ ರೂಪದ ದ್ವೈತರೂಪವಾದ ಜಗತ್ತು – ಜತ್ತಿನಲ್ಲಿ ಅಂದರೆ ಪೃಥ್ವಿಯಲ್ಲಿ; ಜಗತ್ತಿನಲ್ಲಿ ಎಂಬುದನ್ನು ಉಪಲಕ್ಷಣಕ್ಕಾಗಿ (ಉಪಯೋಗಿಸಿರುವುದರಿಂದ) ನಾಮ, ರೂಪ, ಕರ್ಮ – ಎಂಬ ಹೆಸರಿನ ಕಾರ್ಯ ಸಮೂಹವೆಲ್ಲವೂ ಪರಮಾರ್ಥಸತ್ಯವಾಗಿರುವ ಆತ್ಮಭಾವನೆಯಿಂದ ಬಿಟ್ಟು ಹೋಗುವುದು. 
ಹೀಗೆ ಈಶ್ವರಾತ್ಮನೇ ನಾನೆಂಬ ಭಾವನೆಯಿಂದ ಕೂಡಿರುವಾತನು ಪುತ್ರನೇ ಮುಂತಾದ ಏಷಣಾತ್ರಯವನ್ನು  ಬಿಡುವುದಕ್ಕೆ ತಕ್ಕವನೇ ಹೊರತು ಕರ್ಮಗಳಿಗೆ (ತಕ್ಕವ)ನಲ್ಲ. 
ಆದ್ದರಿಂದ, ತ್ಯಕ್ತದಿಂದ ಎಂದರೆ ತ್ಯಾಗದಿಂದ ಎಂದರ್ಥ: (ಬಿಡಲ್ಪಟ್ಟ ಎಂದರ್ಥವಲ್ಲ). ಏಕೆಂದರೆ ಬಿಡಲ್ಪಟ್ಟ ಸತ್ತುಹೋದ ಮಗನಾಗಲಿ ಆಳಾಗಲಿ ತನಗೆ ಸಂಬಂಧವಿಲ್ಲದವನಾದ್ದರಿಂದ ತನ್ನನ್ನು ಕಾಪಾಡಲಾರನು. ಆದ್ದರಿಂದ ತ್ಯಾಗದಿಂದ ಎಂಬುದೇ (ಸರಿಯಾದ) ಅರ್ಥವು. (ತ್ಯಾಗದಿಂದ ನಿನ್ನನ್ನು) ’ಭುಞ್ಜೀಥಾಃ’ ಕಾಪಾಡಿಕೊ. 
ಹೀಗೆ ಬಯಕೆಗಳನ್ನು ಬಿಟ್ಟ ನೀನು ಬಯಸಬೇಡ: ಬಯಕೆಯನ್ನು ಅಂದರೆ ಧನವಿಷಯದ ಆಸೆಯನ್ನು ಮಾಡಬೇಡ. ಯಾರ ಧನವನ್ನೂ-ಮತ್ತೊಬ್ಬನ ಅಥವಾ ನಿನ್ನ ಧನವನ್ನು – ಬಯಸದಿರು ಎಂದರ್ಥ. (ಕಸ್ಯಸ್ವಿತ್) ಎಂಬಲ್ಲಿ ಸ್ವಿತ್ ಎಂಬ ನಿಪಾತಕ್ಕೆ ಯಾವ ಅರ್ಥವೂ ಇಲ್ಲ. ಅಥವಾ (ಈ ವಾಕ್ಯಕ್ಕೆ ಮತ್ತೊಂದು ರೀತಿಯಲ್ಲಿ ಅರ್ಥವನ್ನು ಮಾಡಬಹುದು). ಬಯಸಬೇಡ: ಏಕೆಂದರೆ ಹಣವು ಯಾರದ್ದು? ಎಂದು (ಕಸ್ಯಸ್ವಿತ್ ಎಂಬ ಮಾತನ್ನು) ಆಕ್ಷೇಪಾರ್ಥ (ದಲ್ಲಿ ತೆಗೆದುಕೊಳ್ಳಬೇಕು). ಬಯಸುವುದಕ್ಕೆ ಯಾರ ಹಣವೂ ಇರುವುದಿಲ್ಲ. ’ಇದೆಲ್ಲವೂ ಆತ್ಮನೇ’ ಎಂದು ಈಶ್ವರಭಾವನೆಯಿಂದ ಎಲ್ಲವನ್ನೂ ಬಿಟ್ಟಿದ್ದಾಯಿತು. ಆದ್ದರಿಂದ ಇದೆಲ್ಲವೂ ಆತ್ಮನದೇ. ಇದೆಲ್ಲವೂ ಆತ್ಮನೇ. ಆದ್ದರಿಂದ ಸುಳ್ಳಾದ ವಿಷಯದಲ್ಲಿ ಬಯಕೆಯನ್ನು ಮಾಡಬೇಡ ಎಂದರ್ಥ. 
ಹೀಗೆ ಆತ್ಮನನ್ನು ಅರಿತಿರುವವನು ಪುತ್ರನೇ ಮುಂತಾದ ಏಷಣಾತ್ರಯವನ್ನು ಬಿಟ್ಟು ಆತ್ಮಜ್ಞಾನನಿಷ್ಠನಾಗಿ ತನ್ನನ್ನು ತಾನು ಕಾಪಾಡಿಕೊಳ್ಲಬೆಕೆಂಬುದು (ಮೊದಲನೆಯ) ವೇದವಾಕ್ಯದ ಅರ್ಥವು. ಇನ್ನು ಆನಾತ್ಮಜ್ಞರಾಗಿ ಆತ್ಮನನ್ನು ಅರಿತುಕೊಳ್ಳುವುದಕ್ಕೆ ಶಕ್ತಿಯಿಲ್ಲದ ಮಿಕ್ಕವರಿಗೆ (ಈ ಎರಡನೆಯ) ಮಂತ್ರವು ಇದನ್ನು ಉಪದೇಶಮಾಡುತ್ತದೆ.

इस लोकमें अग्निहोत्रादि कर्म
करते हुए ही सौतक अर्थात् सौ वर्षों-
तक जीनेकी इच्छा करे । पुरुषकी
बड़ी-से-बड़ी आयु इतनी ही
बतलायी गयी है । अतः उस प्राप्त
हुई आयुका अनुवाद करते हुए यह
विधान किया है कि यदि सौ वर्ष
जीनेकी इच्छा करे तो कर्म करते
हुए ही जीना चाहे ।
इस तरह, इस प्रकार जीनेकी इच्छा करनेवाले तुझ मनुष्य मनुष्यत्वमात्रका अभिमान करने- वालेके लिये इस अर्थात् अग्नि- होत्रादि कर्म करते हुए ही [ आयु बितानेके ] वर्तमान प्रकार से भिन्न और कोई ऐसा प्रकार नहीं है जिससे अशुभ कर्मका लेप न हो अर्थात् जिससे वह पुरुष कर्मसे लिप्त न हो । अतः अग्निहोत्र आदि शास्त्रविहित कर्मोंको करते हुए ही जीनेकी इच्छा करे ।
पूर्व ० - यह कैसे जाना गया कि पूर्व मन्त्र से संन्यासीकी ज्ञाननिष्ठाका तथा द्वितीय मन्त्रसे संन्यासमें असमर्थ पुरुषकी कर्मनिष्ठाका वर्णन किया गया है ?
सिद्धान्ती - कहते हैं, क्या तुम्हें स्मरण नहीं है कि, जैसा पहले ( सम्बन्ध-भाष्य में ) कह चुके हैं, ज्ञान और कर्मका विरोध पर्वतके समान अविचल है । यहाँ भी 'जो जीनेकी इच्छा करे वह कर्म करते हुए ही [ जीना चाहे ]" तथा "यह सब ईश्वरसे आच्छादन करनेयोग्य है' 'उस ( चराचर जगत् ) के त्याग- द्वारा आत्माकी रक्षा कर' 'किसीके धनकी इच्छा न कर' इत्यादि वाक्यों- से कर्मी और संन्यासीकी निष्ठाओं- [ का भेद ही ] निरूपण किया है । तथा 'जीवन या मरणका लोभ न करे, वनको चला जाय – यही वेदकी मर्यादा है । और फिर वहाँ- से घर न लौटे' इस वाक्यसे भी [ज्ञाननिष्ठके लिये ] संन्यासका ही विधान किया है । आगे इन दोनों निष्ठाओंके फलका भेद भी बतलायेंगे । ये दोनों ही मार्ग सृष्टिके आरम्भ- से परम्परागत हैं । इनमें पहले कर्ममार्ग है और पीछे संन्यास | [ संन्यासरूप ] निवृत्तिमार्ग से तीनों एषणाओंका त्याग किया जाता है । इन दोनोंमें संन्यासमार्ग ही उत्कर्ष प्राप्त करता है । तैत्तिरीय श्रुतिमें भी कहा है कि "संन्यास ही उत्कृष्टताको प्राप्त हुआ ।" वेदाचार्य भगवान् व्यासने भी बहुत सोच-विचारकर हो अपने पुत्रसे यह निश्चित बात कही है — "जिनमें वेद प्रतिष्ठित हैं ऐसे ये दो ही मार्ग हैं -- एक तो प्रवृत्तिलक्षण धर्ममार्ग और दूसरा अच्छी तरह भावना किया हुआ निवृत्तिमार्ग ।” इन दोनों- का विभाग हम आगे दिखलायेंगे ॥२॥

tellmemore_en_adv: This verse from the Ishavasya Upanishad describes the fate of those who live in ignorance. It talks about dark realms known as 'asurya' which are completely covered in darkness. This darkness represents ignorance and a lack of spiritual knowledge. According to Shankara, people who do not recognize their true self and live without seeking higher knowledge are considered to be killing their own spiritual potential. These individuals, after their death, go to these dark and ignorant realms. The verse highlights the importance of seeking knowledge and understanding one's true nature to avoid such a fate. Living a life focused only on material pursuits and ignoring the spiritual aspect leads to a state of perpetual ignorance and suffering, both in this life and beyond. Therefore, the Upanishad urges people to seek enlightenment and realize their true self to avoid falling into these realms of darkness.
tellmemore_en_dva: In Dvaita philosophy, this verse warns about the severe consequences of acquiring and holding onto erroneous knowledge about God. It states that individuals who misunderstand or misrepresent the nature of God will face dire repercussions after death, being consigned to realms of deep darkness and suffering. These realms are described as hellish worlds, inhabited by demons and filled with immense misery. Before providing the correct understanding of God in the following verses, this verse underscores the importance of having accurate knowledge. Erroneous knowledge can manifest in two ways: either by denying the existence of God or by worshipping Him incorrectly based on false beliefs about His nature. Both forms of wrong knowledge are metaphorically equated to killing God because they distort the truth and lead one away from the path of righteousness. Such mistaken beliefs result in spiritual downfall and prevent one from attaining liberation. Therefore, the verse highlights the necessity of seeking true knowledge and understanding of God to avoid the disastrous consequences of ignorance and misbelief.
tellmemore_en_vis: This verse conveys a warning about the consequences of neglecting the knowledge of Brahman. It states that those who do not seek or gain knowledge of Brahman in this life are destined to go to the worlds enveloped in blinding darkness, known as asuric worlds, after death. These frightening realms, often described as naraka (hell), are where individuals with asuric (demonic) nature end up. The term "आत्महन्" is used metaphorically to describe people who, by ignoring the pursuit of knowledge about Brahman, lead themselves towards spiritual degradation and near non-existence. Such ignorance and neglect result in great sins, causing the self to deteriorate. In Vishishtadvaita, this emphasizes the urgency and importance of acquiring true knowledge and understanding of the Supreme Brahman to avoid such dire consequences and attain liberation.

tellmemore_en_adv:
This verse describes the true nature of the Self (Atman). It explains that the Self is steady and unchanging, yet it is faster than the mind. The senses, like sight and hearing, cannot catch up to it because it is always ahead of them. Even though it doesn't move, it surpasses everything else that moves. This is because the Self is present everywhere and in everything.

Shankara clarifies that the Self doesn't change or move, but it seems to be everywhere because it reflects in everything we perceive. The mind is considered the fastest because it can think of distant places instantly. However, the Self is already there even before the mind can think of it.

The verse also mentions Matariśva, which means the Mukya-Prana, symbolizing the vital force that sustains life. This force, guided by the Self, supports all activities in the universe. The Self remains constant and eternal, making everything else function.

In simpler terms, the Self is the ultimate reality that is constant and everywhere. It moves faster than the mind because it is beyond physical movement. The senses can't perceive it directly because it is beyond them. This Self supports all life and activities in the universe.
tellmemore_en_dva:
In Dvaita philosophy, this verse describes the nature of the Supreme God, emphasizing His immanence and transcendence. It highlights several key attributes of God. First, God is unmoved and fearless, indicating His supreme stability and absence of fear. He is also described as one, the ultimate and supreme being. Although deities and other beings cannot fully grasp or comprehend Him due to His infinite nature, He knows all from the beginning of time.

God is faster than the mind, suggesting His omnipresence and omniscience, able to surpass all thoughts and actions. Despite others running fast, He effortlessly overtakes them, symbolizing His supreme power and presence everywhere.

Mukhya-prana, the chief vital force, plays a crucial role by offering the deeds of all beings to God. This signifies that all actions performed by individuals are ultimately dedicated to and evaluated by God. It highlights the concept that humans are instruments of God, and their actions are a form of worship and devotion aimed at obtaining God's grace.

Understanding these characteristics helps devotees realize that God is the true doer, and by dedicating their actions to Him, they align themselves with divine will and purpose. This realization constitutes the essence of "samarpana" or offering at the feet of God, acknowledging His supreme authority and seeking His blessings.
tellmemore_en_vis:
This sloka highlights the unique and extraordinary nature of Paramatman (Supreme Self) in Vishishtadvaita philosophy. Paramatman is described as "Anejat," meaning unmoving, yet swifter than the mind. This paradoxical nature signifies that while Paramatman is changeless and steady, He transcends the speed and capabilities of the mind. 

The "Devas" or gods, representing various divine forces, cannot fully comprehend Him despite their swift nature because their knowledge is obstructed by Karma. The term "Ayeti Tishthat" suggests that Paramatman, residing as the inner self of all, remains stationary yet overtakes all entities that move. This implies His omnipresence and omnipotence, overseeing and regulating all activities in the universe.

Moreover, "Matarishva" (the Mukya Prana) symbolically carries out its duties by the will of Paramatman, indicating that even natural forces operate under His command. The verse thus underscores the supreme and all-encompassing power of God, who is both immanent and transcendent, providing the foundation and support for all existence. This realization leads to a deeper understanding of the divine presence within and outside, encouraging devotees to seek His grace and guidance.

tellmemore_en_adv: In Advaita philosophy, this verse emphasizes the unique and all-encompassing nature of the Self (Atman). The Self is unmoving and constant, yet it appears to move because it is present in all moving entities. It seems far away to those who are ignorant of its true nature, but it is very near to those who realize it, as it is their innermost essence. The Self is inside everything, being the core of all beings and objects. At the same time, it is outside everything, pervading the entire universe like space. This illustrates the non-dualistic view of Advaita, where the Self is the singular, all-pervasive reality that transcends and includes all existence. It unites everything in a continuous, unbroken presence, highlighting the oneness of all life and existence.
tellmemore_en_dva:
In Dvaita philosophy, this verse emphasizes the omnipresence and omnipotence of God. It conveys that God is the supreme authority whom everything in existence respects and fears. This is because all beings are dependent on Him, while He is independent and fears none.

The verse further describes God's omnipresence by stating that He is both near and far. This means that God is close to us, within our hearts, and also far-reaching, extending beyond the physical universe. His presence is not limited by space or distance, making Him simultaneously accessible and transcendent.

Additionally, God is described as being inside and outside all. He resides within every being, regulating and guiding their actions. At the same time, He exists outside, supporting and sustaining the entire creation. This dual aspect highlights His role as the inner controller and the external sustainer of the universe.

These descriptions illustrate God's infinite nature through paradoxes, showing that He encompasses all opposites and transcends all limitations. His presence and power are absolute, making Him the ultimate source of fear, respect, and reverence.
tellmemore_en_vis:
The verse describes the enigmatic nature of the Supreme Being, portraying it as both dynamic and static, distant and proximate, internal and external. In Vishishtadvaita philosophy, this signifies God's omnipresence and transcendence.

For those ignorant and attached to sensory pleasures, God seems distant, highlighting their spiritual separation from the divine. Conversely, to the devoted who focus their minds on Govinda (Vishnu) and renounce worldly desires, God appears near, illustrating the intimacy and accessibility of the divine through devotion and detachment.

This verse underscores that God pervades all existence, being both immanent within creation and transcendent beyond it. It emphasizes that the perception of God's proximity is determined by one's spiritual awareness and devotion. By recognizing this dual nature, believers are encouraged to seek a deeper connection with the divine, understanding that God is always present, both within and beyond the visible world. This recognition leads to a profound spiritual realization that transcends ordinary perception, inviting a closer, more personal relationship with the divine essence that permeates everything.
tellmemore_hi_adv: जिसका प्रकरण है वह आत्मतत्त्व एजन करता — चलता है, वही स्वयं नहीं भी चलता, अर्थात् स्वयं अचल रहकर ही चलता हुआ-सा जान पड़ता है। यही नहीं, वह दूर भी है; अज्ञानियोंको सैकड़ों करोड़ वर्षोंमें भी अप्राप्य होनेके कारण दूर- जैसा है । [ ' तद्वन्तिके' का ] तत् उ अन्ति- के ऐसा पदच्छेद करना चाहिये । वही अन्तिक - अत्यन्त समीप भी है अर्थात् केवल दूर ही नहीं, विद्वानोंका आत्मा होनेके कारण समीप भी है । वह इस सबके अन्तर यानी भीतर भी है, जैसा कि "जो आत्मा सर्वान्तर हैं" इत्यादि श्रुतिसे सिद्ध होता है । आकाशके समान व्यापक होनेके कारण वह इस नामरूप और क्रियात्मक सम्पूर्ण जगत् के बाहर तथा सूक्ष्मरूप होनेसे इसके भीतर भी है। और श्रुतिके "प्रज्ञानघन ही है" इस कथन के अनुसार वह निरन्तर ( बाहर- भीतरके भेदको त्यागकर सर्वत्र ) ही है ॥ ५ ॥

meaning_kn: ಯಾರು ತನ್ನ ಆತ್ಮದಲ್ಲಿ ಎಲ್ಲವನ್ನೂ ನೋಡುತ್ತಾರೆ ಮತ್ತು ಎಲ್ಲದರಲ್ಲೂ ತನ್ನ ಆತ್ಮವನ್ನು ನೋಡುತ್ತಾರೆ , ಇದರಿಂದ ಅವರು ಯಾವುದೇ ಅಸಹ್ಯವನ್ನು ಅನುಭವಿಸುವುದಿಲ್ಲ.
tellmemore_en_adv: In Advaita philosophy, this verse emphasizes the unity of all existence. It states that one who perceives all beings as manifestations within the Self, and recognizes the Self in all beings, transcends hatred and aversion. This perception comes from understanding that the Self (Atman) is the singular reality underlying all forms of life. When one realizes that every being is not separate but part of the same universal Self, feelings of division and enmity dissolve. This realization leads to a state of pure love and compassion, as there is no 'other' to dislike or hate. Seeing the Self in everything and everything in the Self is the essence of Advaita, promoting a vision of oneness and interconnectedness of all life.
tellmemore_en_dva:
In Dvaita philosophy, this verse emphasizes the unique relationship between God and all beings. It explains that all sentient beings exist within God, and God is present within all of them. This means that God is the ultimate support and regulator of everything in existence.

God being the abode of all implies that He is the foundation and the sustaining force behind all creation. Every being depends on Him for their existence and functioning. At the same time, God's presence within all beings indicates His role as an inner regulator, guiding and controlling their actions from within.

This understanding of God's omnipresence and omnipotence removes all fears, as recognizing His protective and guiding presence brings a sense of security and peace. Since God is all-powerful and independent, He has no need to protect Himself and is free from fear.

The verse also clarifies that there is no identity or sameness between the individual self and God. The relationship is one of dependence and regulation, not of oneness or merger. The use of the locative case indicates a clear distinction between God and the individual beings.
tellmemore_en_vis:
The verse offers profound insight into the nature of realization and unity in Vishishtadvaita philosophy. It suggests that a person who truly sees all beings within the Supreme Self and the Supreme Self within all beings transcends any form of aversion or contempt. This vision is not a superficial understanding but a deep, continuous contemplation that all entities, from the highest deity to the smallest living being, reside within Paramatman, the Supreme Soul.

Such a person perceives that the Supreme Soul is the inner essence of all beings, supporting and sustaining them. This realization brings about a profound change in perspective, where one no longer sees distinctions and separations but rather an underlying unity. The Supreme Soul is recognized as the true Self of all, permeating and existing within everything. This understanding eliminates any feelings of hatred or aversion, as one realizes that harming another is essentially harming oneself.

The verse emphasizes the importance of perceiving this unity, which leads to universal love and compassion. It signifies that the realization of the omnipresence of the Supreme Soul in all beings and all beings within the Supreme Soul is the foundation for ethical and harmonious living. This deeper understanding fosters a sense of oneness and respect for all life forms, highlighting the core principle of Vishishtadvaita that the Supreme Being, though distinct, is intimately connected with all aspects of the universe.

tellmemore_en_adv: In Advaita philosophy, this verse emphasizes the ultimate realization of oneness. It states that for a person who truly understands that all beings are manifestations of the Self, there is no room for delusion or sorrow. This realization comes from seeing the unity of all existence in the Self (Atman). When one perceives that everything is interconnected and that there is no true separation between beings, the causes of sorrow and confusion disappear. This state of awareness eliminates the ignorance that leads to feelings of isolation and suffering. The seer of oneness understands that all forms of life are essentially the same pure consciousness, leading to a state of eternal peace and bliss. In Advaita, this recognition of the non-dual nature of reality is the key to transcending all mental afflictions and achieving liberation.
tellmemore_en_dva:
In Dvaita philosophy, this verse reiterates the fundamental understanding that God is the ultimate support and regulator of all beings. All creatures find their foundation and sustenance in God, and He is present within each one of them, guiding and controlling their actions.

A person who truly understands that God is both the support and the inner regulator of all beings, and perceives the unity of God's presence in everyone, will be free from misconceptions and sorrow. This deep knowledge dispels erroneous beliefs and the grief that comes from such misunderstandings. Recognizing God's omnipresence and His role as the sustainer and regulator provides a sense of peace and clarity.

The verse emphasizes that there is no claim of identity between the individual self and all other beings. Instead, it highlights the distinction while acknowledging God's pervasive presence. By seeing God in all, a person transcends wrong knowledge and sorrow, attaining a state of true understanding and inner peace.
tellmemore_en_vis:
This verse emphasizes the state of realization where one perceives the Supreme Self as the essence within all beings. For a person who has attained this knowledge and sees all entities as manifestations of the Supreme Self, the concepts of delusion and sorrow become irrelevant. This realization comes from deep meditation and understanding the inherent unity in diversity.

The term "vijanatah" refers to one who has discerned the difference between the Independent Reality (Paramatman) and dependent entities (jivatman) as taught in the scriptures. Such a person sees Paramatman alone as characterized by all, rejecting theories of sublation, secondary application, or identity in nature.

This verse aims to affirm that Brahman is the self of all and that true knowledge dispels all delusions and sorrows by realizing that everything belongs to and is pervaded by Paramatman. This profound understanding leads to a state where no external loss, such as the death of a loved one or the loss of a kingdom, can cause grief, as everything is seen as part of the divine essence.

tellmemore_en_adv:
This verse describes the Self (Atman) as an entity that permeates everything in existence. It is entirely pure and without any physical form or body, meaning it doesn't suffer from wounds or have physical structures like sinews. The Self is immaculate and untouched by any form of sin or impurity. It possesses complete and infinite knowledge, understanding all things. Additionally, it is the master and guide of the mind, directing all mental processes. The Self transcends all physical and mental limitations, existing beyond the constraints of the material world. It exists independently, not relying on anything else for its being.

The verse also indicates that the Self has a role in organizing and maintaining the universe by assigning duties and functions to various entities and forces, ensuring the smooth and orderly operation of everything. This portrays the Self as the ultimate, unchanging reality that underlies and supports all existence, embodying the core principles of Advaita philosophy, which emphasize the unity and oneness of all life.

Thus, this verse reveals the Self as the pure, all-knowing, and ever-present essence that governs and transcends the universe, encouraging a deeper understanding of the interconnected and eternal nature of all existence.
tellmemore_en_dva:
In Dvaita philosophy, this verse highlights the attributes of God and their significance for the knower. God is described as being beyond sorrow, without a subtle body (linga sarira) or gross body, free from any limitations of time or attributes, and the embodiment of all purity. God is also unaffected by any sin, making Him the perfect being.

Understanding and realizing these attributes of God helps the devotee overcome false knowledge and sorrow. By knowing God in this way, one can see the true nature of existence and find peace.

The verse also emphasizes that God, who is omniscient and the lord of all minds, controls everything independently and has created the world truly throughout the ages. This underscores the reality of the world, countering the idea that the world is merely an illusion. Instead, it affirms that God has genuinely created the world with purpose and meaning.

The adjectives used to describe God convey His perfection and transcendence. God's lack of a subtle or gross body means He is not bound by physical limitations, yet He possesses a unique, divine form that allows Him to create and sustain the universe effortlessly.

Thus, this verse in Dvaita philosophy explains that knowing the true attributes of God—His purity, perfection, and independence—leads to liberation from false knowledge and sorrow. It affirms the reality of the world as a true creation of the divine, highlighting the importance of understanding God's true nature.
tellmemore_en_vis: This verse describes the Supreme Brahman as pure and self-luminous, free from bodily imperfections or sins, and self-existent. It highlights Brahman as the seer, knower, and controller, possessing complete wisdom and insight. Brahman is free from the limitations of a physical body, symbolizing purity and transcendence over material impurities. This Supreme Entity understands the true nature of all things and governs them eternally. The verse can also be interpreted to signify that a realized soul, or Sadhaka, who attains such knowledge of Brahman, embodies these divine qualities, achieving supreme purity and eternal wisdom through disciplined practice and devotion. This interpretation underscores the essence of Vishishtadvaita, which emphasizes the unity of the individual soul with Brahman, while still maintaining their distinct identities.

tellmemore_en_vis:
This verse from the Ishavasya Upanishad emphasizes the pitfalls of focusing solely on either ignorance or mere knowledge. It says that those who engage in ignorance (avidya), which refers to ritualistic actions and material pursuits, end up in a state of deep spiritual darkness. This darkness symbolizes a lack of true understanding and awareness. However, the verse goes further to state that those who are only focused on knowledge (vidya), such as intellectual learning or meditation on gods without deeper realization, fall into an even greater darkness.

In simpler terms, both mere ritualistic practices and intellectual pursuits without true understanding are inadequate paths. Solely performing rituals without understanding their deeper significance keeps one in ignorance. On the other hand, engaging in knowledge without practical application or spiritual realization can lead to a false sense of superiority and greater confusion.

Advaita philosophy teaches that a balance is necessary. True wisdom comes from integrating both knowledge and action, leading to a deeper realization of the Self. This integrated approach helps transcend the limitations of both ignorance and superficial knowledge, leading to ultimate enlightenment and liberation.
tellmemore_kn_adv:
In Dvaita philosophy, this verse emphasizes the importance of both acquiring correct knowledge of God and actively denouncing incorrect knowledge. It warns that those who hold and propagate wrong knowledge about God will end up in a state of deep spiritual darkness, filled with ignorance and suffering. This idea was previously mentioned and is reiterated here to emphasize its seriousness.

However, the verse also highlights an additional responsibility: those who possess right knowledge about God but fail to criticize or correct wrong knowledge are at even greater risk. If knowledgeable individuals do not challenge misconceptions and false beliefs about God, they fail in their duty to uphold and spread the truth. This negligence can lead to greater spiritual consequences for them, including deeper darkness and confusion.

The word "avidya" here refers to the wrong understanding or misrepresentation of God's nature. People with correct knowledge understand the harmful effects of such misconceptions and have the responsibility to address and correct them. Ignoring this duty can result in severe spiritual repercussions, as it allows falsehoods to persist and mislead others.
Thus, this verse in Dvaita philosophy teaches that having correct knowledge about God is not enough. It is equally important to actively oppose and correct wrong knowledge to prevent spiritual darkness and confusion. Both acquiring right knowledge and denouncing false beliefs are essential for maintaining spiritual integrity and guiding others on the correct path.
tellmemore_kn_dva:
In this verse, the text emphasizes the significance of integrating both karma (actions) and vidya (knowledge) for achieving moksha (liberation). Those who solely focus on karma without understanding or meditating on the Supreme Being are likened to entering blinding darkness, symbolizing ignorance. On the other hand, those who solely indulge in vidya without the support of karma are considered to fall into even greater darkness.

Vishishtadvaita philosophy stresses the importance of performing one’s ordained duties (Varnasrama Dharma) along with meditating on the Supreme Being. Karma, when performed with devotion and the right knowledge, purifies the mind and leads one closer to liberation. Hence, the synthesis of karma and vidya is crucial for spiritual progress.

The deeper implication is that neither mere ritualistic actions nor mere intellectual knowledge alone can lead to true enlightenment. It is the harmonious blend of action and wisdom, guided by devotion and understanding of the Supreme Self, that dispels ignorance and leads to liberation. This approach underscores the Vishishtadvaita view that devotion (bhakti), knowledge (jnana), and righteous action (karma) together form the path to moksha.

meaning_en: “They say that the results achieved by knowledge are very different from those achieved by ignorance.” Thus, we have heard from the wise who have explained this to us.

tellmemore_en_adv:
In this verse, the Ishavasya Upanishad discusses the distinct outcomes of following the paths of knowledge (vidya) and ignorance (avidya). The verse states that different results are attained depending on whether one pursues knowledge or remains in ignorance. This distinction has been passed down by wise teachers who have explained these differences.

By following the path of knowledge, one attains a higher spiritual understanding and realization of the Self. This leads to liberation and a deeper connection with the divine. On the other hand, engaging in ignorance, which involves merely performing rituals and focusing on material pursuits, results in a different, more limited outcome.

The wise teachers, or sages, have conveyed that knowledge and ignorance lead to distinct paths and results. The path of knowledge ultimately leads to spiritual enlightenment and liberation, while the path of ignorance keeps one bound to the cycle of birth and death, focused on transient, worldly gains.

Thus, this verse highlights the importance of pursuing knowledge over ignorance, as they lead to very different spiritual destinations. Understanding and following the teachings of the wise can guide one towards the path of true realization and liberation.
tellmemore_en_dva: In Dvaita philosophy, this verse underscores that the outcomes of right knowledge and the censure of wrong knowledge are distinct but both are crucial for liberation. The wise have conveyed that understanding the true nature of God leads to one set of results, while actively correcting false beliefs about God leads to another. Right knowledge brings about the realization of divine bliss, allowing one to experience the truth and dispel ignorance. This connection with the divine fosters a deeper spiritual fulfillment. Conversely, the censure of wrong knowledge plays a vital role in eliminating sorrow and ignorance. By addressing and correcting misconceptions, one helps to purify the mind and create a conducive environment for true understanding. These teachings emphasize that both the acquisition of correct knowledge and the correction of falsehoods are necessary for a comprehensive approach to spiritual growth. Through this dual approach, one can achieve both the elimination of ignorance and the realization of divine bliss, as taught by the wise sages.
tellmemore_en_vis: This verse states that the wise men say the results of vidya (knowledge) and avidya (ignorance or ritual actions) are different. According to Vishishtadvaita, knowledge refers to meditation on and understanding of Paramatman, while avidya refers to ritualistic actions. The wise teach that the path to liberation involves both elements: knowledge alone or actions alone are insufficient. True liberation is attained by integrating knowledge with karma, performing one's duties with devotion to God and understanding of His supreme nature. This holistic approach ensures purity of mind and realization of the ultimate truth. Thus, the ancient teachings emphasize the necessity of balancing knowledge and action in the pursuit of liberation.

tellmemore_en_adv:
This verse from the Ishavasya Upanishad highlights the importance of understanding and balancing both knowledge (vidya) and ignorance (avidya) in one's spiritual journey. The verse states that a person who understands both knowledge and ignorance together can achieve two significant outcomes.

First, by understanding and engaging in ignorance, which refers to performing rituals and following prescribed duties (avidya), one can overcome the fear of death. This means that through the disciplined practice of rituals and duties, one can transcend the immediate concerns and limitations of mortal life.

Second, by embracing and practicing knowledge (vidya), which refers to the deeper spiritual wisdom and meditation, one can attain immortality. This immortality is not about living forever in a physical sense but achieving a state of eternal unity with the divine or the ultimate reality.

The wise person, who can balance both the practical aspects of life through rituals and the deeper spiritual quest through meditation and knowledge, can navigate the challenges of life and death and ultimately reach a state of eternal bliss and enlightenment.

Thus, the verse teaches that a harmonious understanding and practice of both worldly duties and spiritual wisdom are essential for overcoming the limitations of mortal life and attaining the highest state of spiritual fulfillment and immortality.
tellmemore_en_dva: In Dvaita philosophy, this verse emphasizes the importance of both possessing right knowledge and actively correcting wrong knowledge to achieve liberation. The verse highlights that these two actions lead to different, yet complementary, outcomes in the path to spiritual freedom. By censuring wrong knowledge, one can overcome ignorance and sorrow, which are metaphorically referred to as death. This act of correcting misconceptions purifies the mind, removing obstacles that hinder spiritual progress. On the other hand, possessing right knowledge about the true nature of God leads to the attainment of a blissful state. This knowledge provides a clear understanding of the divine and fosters a deeper connection with the ultimate reality, resulting in spiritual fulfillment and joy. Therefore, the verse elaborates that both the elimination of false beliefs and the acquisition of true knowledge are essential for crossing over the metaphorical death of ignorance and sorrow, and for attaining the state of divine bliss.
tellmemore_en_vis:
In this verse, the Upanishad states that one who understands both knowledge (vidya) and ignorance (avidya) together can attain liberation. Vidya refers to the higher knowledge or upasana (meditation on the Supreme), while avidya represents karma (ritualistic actions). The verse suggests that by transcending death through karma and attaining immortality through meditation, one can achieve the ultimate realization. This reinforces the idea that both aspects are essential and complementary in the pursuit of liberation, as karma serves as a foundation for the higher knowledge that leads to moksha (liberation).

In the Vishishtadvaita philosophy, Ramanuja interprets this mantra to emphasize the inseparable relationship between karma (rituals and duties) and jnana (knowledge). He argues that karma supports and enhances meditation on the Supreme (upasana). Vidya, as meditation on the Supreme, leads to the realization of Paramatman, while karma helps in purifying the mind and preparing it for this higher pursuit. This combined practice enables the seeker to overcome the limitations imposed by past actions (karma) and achieve a direct experience of the Supreme, ultimately leading to liberation.

tellmemore_en_adv:
This verse highlights the pitfalls of worshipping either the unmanifested (Prakrti) or the manifested (Hiranyagarbha) without deeper spiritual understanding. It says that those who worship the Unmanifested, which refers to Prakrti or the primal material cause, fall into deep spiritual darkness. This is because they focus on the material aspect of the universe, which is associated with ignorance and blindness to the true nature of the Self.

On the other hand, those who are devoted to the Manifested, such as Hiranyagarbha (the cosmic golden egg or the manifested universe), fall into even greater darkness. This is because, while they recognize the existence of the divine in a manifest form, they still miss the ultimate realization of the Self, which is beyond all forms and manifestations.

The verse suggests that both types of worship, whether of the unmanifested material cause or the manifested cosmic being, are incomplete and lead to spiritual ignorance. True enlightenment comes from transcending both these aspects and realizing the non-dual nature of the Self, which encompasses and transcends both the manifested and unmanifested.

Thus, the verse teaches that exclusive devotion to either the unmanifested or the manifested aspects of the universe can lead to deeper ignorance, and emphasizes the need for a more holistic spiritual understanding that goes beyond these dualities.
tellmemore_en_dva:
In Dvaita philosophy, this verse underscores the importance of understanding the full nature of God as both creator and destroyer. It warns that meditating on God with the mistaken belief that He is not the creator leads one into a state of deep spiritual darkness, filled with ignorance and misconception. This kind of erroneous knowledge signifies a lack of proper understanding of the scriptures, which clearly describe God as the creator of the universe.

However, the verse also cautions against the incomplete belief that God is only the creator and not the destroyer. Such a belief leads to even deeper darkness because it fails to recognize the comprehensive nature of God's role in the cosmos. God is not only responsible for creation but also for destruction, preservation, and transformation. Recognizing Him solely as the creator is a greater lapse since it shows a partial understanding of divine functions, ignoring the fact that destruction is also a necessary aspect of the divine order, enabling renewal and balance in the universe.

This explanation highlights the consequences of holding incomplete or incorrect views about God. Both types of misunderstandings lead to spiritual darkness, but failing to acknowledge God's role as both creator and destroyer represents a more significant error. Understanding God's complete nature is essential for true spiritual insight and liberation.
tellmemore_en_vis:
This verse highlights the consequences of worshipping the Unmanifest and the Manifest separately. Asambhuti refers to the Unmanifested Prakriti, and Sambhuti refers to the manifested forms like deities. Worshipping the Unmanifest alone leads to ignorance and darkness. However, being devoted exclusively to the Manifest is considered even more detrimental. The verse emphasizes the necessity of understanding and integrating both aspects to attain true knowledge and enlightenment. In Vishishtadvaita, the integration of worship and understanding of the Lord's manifested and unmanifested forms is crucial for spiritual progress.

This verse continues from previous teachings about the importance of combining knowledge (vidya) and action (avidya). It serves as a caution against exclusive attachment to either aspect, urging a balanced and holistic approach to spiritual practice.

meaning_en: “They spoke of different outcomes from the worship of the Manifested and the Unmanifested,” thus we have heard from the wise who have explained this to us.
meaning_hi: कार्यब्रह्मकी उपासनासे और ही फल बतलाया गया है; तथा अव्यक्तोपासनासे और ही फलं बतलाया है । ऐसा हमने बुद्धिमानोंसे सुना है, जिन्होंने हमारे प्रति उसकी व्याख्या की थी ॥ १३ ॥
meaning_kn: ಹಿರಣ್ಯಗರ್ಭನ ಆರಾಧನೆಯಿಂದ ಒಂದು ಫಲಿತಾಂಶ ಮತ್ತು ಇನ್ನೊಂದು ಪ್ರಕೃತಿಯ ಆರಾಧನೆಯಿಂದ ಉಂಟಾಗುತ್ತದೆ ಎಂದು ಅವರು ಹೇಳುತ್ತಾರೆ. ಅದನ್ನು ನಮಗೆ ಕಲಿಸಿದ ಬುದ್ಧಿವಂತ ಬೋಧಕರು ಹೀಗೆ ಹೇಳುವುದನ್ನು ನಾವು ಕೇಳಿದ್ದೇವೆ.
tellmemore_en_adv:
This verse from the Ishavasya Upanishad highlights the distinct outcomes of worshipping the Manifested (Sambhuti) and the Unmanifested (Asambhuti). It says that the wise men have taught that the results of worshipping the Manifested and the Unmanifested are different.

Worshipping the Manifested refers to the devotion towards visible forms and deities, such as Hiranyagarbha (the cosmic golden egg or the manifested universe). This kind of worship leads to certain spiritual achievements and supernatural powers, which are still within the realm of the material world.

On the other hand, worshipping the Unmanifested refers to devotion towards the primal, unseen cause (Prakrti or Primordial Nature), which is beyond physical forms. This kind of worship aims for absorption into the unmanifested essence, leading to merging with the fundamental nature of the universe.

The wise sages have explained that these two types of worship lead to different spiritual results. Understanding this distinction helps seekers choose their path based on their spiritual goals.

In summary, the verse emphasizes that the paths of worshipping the Manifested and the Unmanifested yield different outcomes, and the teachings of the wise help in understanding these differences. This understanding is crucial for those on a spiritual journey to make informed choices about their practices.
tellmemore_en_dva:
In Dvaita philosophy, this verse emphasizes the importance of understanding both the creative and destructive aspects of God's nature. The wise sages have taught that recognizing God solely as the creator and understanding Him as the destroyer as well leads to distinct outcomes on the path to liberation. The previous verse mentioned that failing to acknowledge God's role as the destroyer, along with His creatorship, results in spiritual darkness. Here, it is explained that realizing both aspects brings about different, but complementary, results that are essential for achieving liberation.

Understanding God as the creator allows one to appreciate the beginning and sustenance of life and the universe. This realization fosters a sense of gratitude and reverence towards the divine creative power. On the other hand, recognizing God as the destroyer acknowledges the natural cycle of birth, death, and renewal. This comprehension helps one accept the impermanence of life and the necessity of destruction for transformation and growth.

These distinct understandings contribute to a holistic view of God's nature and the universe. The wise teach that both aspects are crucial for spiritual growth and liberation. The next verse will further elaborate on these outcomes and how they contribute to the ultimate goal of liberation.
tellmemore_en_vis: This verse emphasizes the distinct outcomes of worshiping the manifested and unmanifested aspects of the divine. The sages assert that the results derived from worshiping the manifested Brahman (sambhava) differ from those obtained through the unmanifested Brahman (asambhava). This differentiation is vital for practitioners to understand the unique benefits of each form of worship. The wise have conveyed this clarity to us, indicating the necessity of integrating both aspects in spiritual practice to achieve comprehensive knowledge and ultimate liberation.
tellmemore_hi_adv:
सम्भूति अर्थात् कार्यब्रह्मकी उपासना से प्राप्त होनेवाला अणि- मादि ऐश्वर्यरूप और ही फल बत-
लाया अर्थात् बखान किया है । तथा असम्भूति यानी अव्याकृत से अर्थात् अव्याकृत प्रकृतिकी उपा- सनासे और ही फल बतलाया है; जिसे पहले 'अन्धन्तमः प्रविशन्ति' आदि वाक्यसे कह चुके हैं तथा पौराणिक लोग जिसे प्रकृतिलय कहते हैं - ऐसा हमने धीरों ( बुद्धि- मानों ) का कथन सुना है, जिन्होंने हमसे उनका वर्णन किया था अर्थात् व्यक्त और अव्यक्त उपास-
नाओंके फलका व्याख्यान किया था ॥ १३ ॥

sutra:

transliteration_kn:

meaning_en: He who understands both the Unmanifested and Destruction together can cross over death through Destruction and attain immortality through the Unmanifested.

meaning_kn: ಅವ್ಯಕ್ತವಾದ ಪ್ರಕೃತಿ ಮತ್ತು ಹಿರಣ್ಯಗರ್ಭವನ್ನು (ವಿನಾಶ) ಒಟ್ಟಿಗೆ ಪೂಜಿಸುವವರು ಹಿರಣ್ಯಗರ್ಭದ ಉಪಾಸನೆಯಿಂದ ಮರಣವನ್ನು ಪಡೆಯುತ್ತಾರೆ ಮತ್ತು ಪ್ರಕೃತಿಯ ಉಪಾಸನೆಯಿಂದ ಅಮರತ್ವವನ್ನು ಪಡೆಯುತ್ತಾರೆ .
tellmemore_en_adv:
This verse explains the importance of understanding and integrating both the Unmanifested (Prakrti) and the Manifested (Hiranyagarbha) aspects of existence in one's spiritual practice. It states that a person who comprehends both these aspects together can achieve significant spiritual outcomes.

The Unmanifested, referred to as Prakrti, represents the primal, unseen cause of the universe. By worshipping and understanding this aspect, one can attain immortality, which means reaching a state of eternal unity with the fundamental essence of the universe.

The Manifested, represented by Hiranyagarbha, is the cosmic being or the manifested universe. By understanding and integrating this aspect, one can overcome the limitations and fears associated with mortality and the physical world.

In simpler terms, the verse teaches that a balanced understanding and practice of both the Unmanifested and Manifested aspects lead to spiritual liberation and overcoming the cycle of birth and death. It emphasizes the need for a holistic approach that includes both the unseen, primal essence and the visible, manifested forms of the divine.
tellmemore_en_dva:
In Dvaita philosophy, this verse highlights the importance of understanding both the creative and destructive roles of God for achieving complete liberation. It teaches that knowing God as both creator and destroyer leads to distinct but complementary outcomes that are essential for spiritual freedom.

Understanding God's destroyership helps one to transcend the bondage of the body and material existence. This knowledge allows an individual to accept the natural cycle of destruction, which includes death and dissolution, and helps to free oneself from the attachment to the physical form and material possessions. By recognizing that destruction is a part of the divine order, one can overcome the fear of loss and change, leading to inner liberation from worldly ties.

On the other hand, knowing God as the creator, and acknowledging His infinite qualities, brings about a state of bliss. This understanding fosters a deep appreciation for the divine creative power that brings forth and sustains life. It encompasses not just the act of creation but all the positive qualities of God, such as love, compassion, and wisdom. This realization fills the devotee with joy and a sense of connection to the divine, leading to spiritual fulfillment and bliss.

Together, these two aspects of knowledge—God as both creator and destroyer—provide a holistic view of the divine and facilitate a balanced approach to spiritual growth. They help the seeker to transcend physical and material limitations and to achieve a state of ultimate bliss through a comprehensive understanding of God's nature.
tellmemore_en_vis:
He who knows both sambhuti (manifestation) and asambhuti (non-manifestation) together, crosses over death by asambhuti and attains immortality by sambhuti.

In this verse, the importance of understanding both creation (sambhuti) and destruction (asambhuti) is highlighted. Vinasa, representing destruction or dissolution, helps one transcend death and obstacles to attaining the Supreme. Sambhuti, symbolizing creation and manifestation, leads to achieving the immortal state or union with Brahman. This underscores the balance and comprehension of both creation and dissolution in one's spiritual journey. Understanding the dual aspects of reality is essential for overcoming the cycle of birth and death, ultimately achieving liberation.

Here, vinasa implies the cessation of actions and thoughts that bind the soul to the material world, while sambhuti refers to the realization and contemplation of the Supreme Self, leading to liberation. This interpretation emphasizes the need for a holistic approach, integrating both aspects of spiritual practice to attain the ultimate goal of moksha (liberation).
tellmemore_hi_adv:

sutra:

transliteration_kn:

meaning_en: The face of the Truth (Brahman in the solar orb) is hidden by a golden vessel. O Sun, open it so that I, who am truthful and dutiful, may see the Truth.
meaning_hi: आदित्यमण्डलस्थ ब्रह्मका मुख ज्योतिर्मय पात्रसे ढका हुआ है । हे पूषन् ! मुझ सत्यधर्माको आत्माकी उपलब्धि करानेके लिये तू उसे उघाड़ दे ॥ १५ ॥
meaning_kn: ಸತ್ಯದ ಪ್ರವೇಶದ್ವಾರವು ಚಿನ್ನದ ಪಾತ್ರೆಯಿಂದ ಮುಚ್ಚಲ್ಪಟ್ಟಿದೆ. ಓ ಸೂರ್ಯನೇ, "ಸತ್ಯ"ವನ್ನು ಆರಾಧಿಸುತ್ತಿರುವ ನಾನು ಅದನ್ನು ನೋಡಬಹುದಾದ ಹೊದಿಕೆಯನ್ನು ತೆಗೆದುಹಾಕಿ.
tellmemore_en_adv:
In this verse, the seeker is addressing the Sun, which symbolizes the supreme truth or Brahman. The "golden vessel" represents the dazzling and resplendent nature of the physical sun that hides the deeper spiritual reality. The seeker requests the Sun to remove this golden cover so that the true essence of Brahman, which is hidden behind this radiance, can be revealed.

The seeker identifies themselves as someone devoted to the truth and performing righteous duties. They ask the Sun to unveil the ultimate truth for them, allowing them to see and realize the true nature of Brahman.

In simpler terms, this verse is a prayer to the divine to remove the obstacles that prevent one from seeing the ultimate reality. It expresses a deep yearning to transcend the superficial and reach the core of spiritual truth.
tellmemore_en_dva:
In Dvaita philosophy, this verse is a heartfelt prayer by the devotee seeking a direct vision of God and His grace. The devotee acknowledges that God's face, which is full of auspicious qualities, is covered by the brilliance of the sun (Suryamandala). This radiance makes it difficult for the devotee to see God's true form.

The devotee calls upon Pushan, an aspect of the Sun God, who is infinite and nourishing, to unveil this brilliance. By doing so, the devotee hopes to gain a clear vision of God. The prayer reflects a deep yearning for divine revelation and the grace necessary to achieve liberation. The devotee expresses a sincere desire to see God directly, removing the veil of the sun's radiance that hides His form.

These verses form a continuous prayer, where the devotee repeatedly appeals for God's grace and vision. The brilliance of the sun symbolizes the overwhelming and blinding splendor of God's divine presence. By requesting Pushan to unveil this brilliance, the devotee seeks a more personal and direct experience of the divine.

Thus, this verse represents the devotee's earnest prayer to Pushan to reveal God's form, allowing for a deeper connection and vision of the divine. This vision is seen as essential for attaining God's grace and ultimately achieving liberation.
tellmemore_en_vis:
The face of Truth (Brahman) is concealed by a golden vessel (symbolizing the illusions and desires of the material world). The devotee prays to Pushan (a form of the Sun, representing the Supreme Lord) to remove this covering so that the seeker, who is dedicated to the path of righteousness (Satya Dharma), may perceive the true nature of Brahman.

In Vishishtadvaita philosophy, this mantra emphasizes the need for divine grace to overcome the obstacles created by Rajas (passion) that hide the true nature of the Self. The golden vessel represents the allure of material pleasures that distract the mind from spiritual truth. By removing this veil, the aspirant seeks the direct vision of the Supreme, which is the ultimate goal of human life. This prayer highlights the importance of God's intervention to achieve true knowledge and liberation.
tellmemore_hi_adv:

meaning_en: O Nourisher, solitary traveller, controller, acquirer, and son of Prajapati, please withdraw your rays and gather your brilliance. I wish to see your most auspicious form. I am that very being within the sun.
meaning_hi: हे जगत्पोषक सूर्य ! हे एकाकी गमन करनेवाले ! हे यम ( संसारका नियमन करनेवाले ) ! हे सूर्य ( प्राण और रसका शोषण करनेवाले ) ! हे प्रजापतिनन्दन ! तू अपनी किरणोंको हटा ले ( अपने तेजको समेट ले ) । तेरा जो अतिशय कल्याणमय रूप है उसे मैं देखता हूँ । यह जो आदित्यमण्डलस्थ पुरुष है वह मैं हूँ ॥ १६ ॥

tellmemore_en_adv:
In this verse, the seeker addresses the Sun with various epithets, recognizing its different roles and attributes. The Sun is called Pusan, the nourisher, because it sustains life on Earth. It is also referred to as the solitary traveller (Ekarshi), as it moves alone through the sky. The Sun is named Yama, the controller, because it regulates time and life cycles. Prajapatya means the son of Prajapati, the creator god, emphasizing the Sun's divine origin.

The seeker asks the Sun to remove its rays and gather its dazzling light, which symbolizes the physical brightness that hides the deeper spiritual truth. The seeker desires to see the Sun's most auspicious and benign form, which represents the ultimate reality or Brahman.

Finally, the seeker declares their unity with the divine by stating that the person (Purusha) present in the Sun is the same as themselves. This reflects the Advaita philosophy, where the individual self (Atman) is ultimately the same as the universal Self (Brahman).
tellmemore_en_dva:
In Dvaita philosophy, this verse is a prayer to God, recognizing Him through various divine attributes and requesting His grace for enlightenment and vision. The devotee addresses God by different names, each reflecting a specific attribute:

Pushan: The infinite nourisher and sustainer.
Ekarshe: The prime knower of all things, possessing ultimate wisdom.
Yama: The regulator of all, who maintains order and justice.
Surya: The source of knowledge, realized by the learned.
Prajapatya: The one to be attained by Hiranyagarbha, the cosmic soul.
The devotee prays for the knowledge of their true nature and an understanding of the external world. This dual knowledge encompasses self-realization and the comprehension of God's creation. The prayer seeks to see God's auspicious form, which symbolizes divine grace and the ultimate truth.

The verse also highlights that God embodies these attributes and is present in various forms, including Mukhyaprana (the chief vital force). The devotee acknowledges that God is free from inauspicious qualities and is ever-present, both within and beyond themselves.

The prayer thus conveys a deep yearning for divine knowledge and the vision of God's true form, recognizing God's omnipresence and various attributes. It reflects a holistic approach to spirituality, seeking both self-realization and a broader understanding of the divine order.

In this prayer, the devotee appeals to God's different aspects, recognizing His omnipresence and multifaceted nature, and seeks His grace to attain true knowledge and liberation.
tellmemore_en_vis:
In this verse, the seeker prays to the Sun deity, who represents the Supreme Brahman, to reveal His true form by withdrawing His dazzling rays. In Vishishtadvaita, Pushan is understood as the Supreme Being who is the inner controller (Antaryamin) and the one who guides the intellect of His devotees.

- Pushan signifies the nurturing aspect of God, who sustains and protects all beings.
- Ekarshi refers to God as the sole seer, who perceives all things beyond the limitations of ordinary senses.
- Yama represents the regulator, who maintains cosmic order and justice.
- Surya symbolizes the Supreme Light of consciousness that illuminates all knowledge.
- Prajapatya indicates that God is the progenitor of all beings.

The term "Purusha" here is significant. In Vishishtadvaita, it indicates the Supreme Self (Paramatman) who pervades all beings as their innermost essence. The devotee acknowledges that this divine presence is the true self within (Ahamgrahopasana). The repeated use of "Purusha" and "asmi" (I am) emphasizes the identification of the self with the Supreme Being through devotion and meditation.

By praying for the removal of the dazzling rays, the devotee seeks the grace to perceive God's most auspicious and benign form. This vision represents the ultimate realization of the soul's unity with the Supreme, leading to liberation and eternal bliss.
tellmemore_hi_adv:
हे पूषन् ! जगत्का पोषण करनेके कारण सूर्य पूषा है ।
वह अकेला ही चलता है इसलिये एकर्षि है— हे एक !  सबका नियमन करनेके कारण यम है - हे यम ! किरण प्राण और रसोंको स्वीकार करनेके कारण सूर्य है - हे सूर्य ! प्रजापतिका पुत्र होनेसे प्राजापत्य है - हे प्राजापत्य !
अपनी किरणोंको दूर कर । अपने तेज यानी सन्तप्त करनेवाली ज्योतिको पुञ्जीभूत एकत्रित अर्थात् शान्त कर । तेरा जो अत्यन्त कल्याणमय अर्थात् परम सुन्दर स्वरूप है उसे तुझ आत्माकी कृपासे मैं देखता हूँ । तथा यह बात मैं तुझसे सेवकके समान याचना नहीं करता, क्योंकि यह जो व्याहृतिरूप अङ्गोंवाली आदित्यमण्डलस्थ पुरुष है— जो पुरुषाकार होनेसे, अथवा जो प्राण और बुद्धिरूपसे समस्त जगत्को पूर्ण किये हुए है या जो शरीररूप पुरमें शयन करनेके कारण पुरुष है - वह मैं ही हूँ ॥ १६ ॥

meaning_en: Let my vital force merge with the all-pervading immortal air, and let this body be reduced to ashes. OM, O mind, remember – remember all that has been done. Remember – remember all that has been done.
meaning_hi: अब मेरा प्राण सर्वात्मक वायुरूप सूत्रात्माको प्राप्त हो और यह शरीर भस्मशेष हो जाय । हे मेरे संकल्पात्मक मन ! अब तू स्मरण कर, अपने किये हुएको स्मरण कर, अब तू स्मरण कर, अपने किये हुएको स्मरण कर ॥ १७ ॥
meaning_kn: (ನನ್ನ) ಪ್ರಾಣವು ಸರ್ವವ್ಯಾಪಿಯಾದ ವಾಯು, ಶಾಶ್ವತ ಸೂತ್ರಾತ್ಮನಲ್ಲಿ ಕರಗಲಿ ; ಮತ್ತು ಈ ದೇಹವನ್ನು ಬೆಂಕಿಯಿಂದ ಸುಟ್ಟು ಬೂದಿ ಮಾಡಲಿ; ಓಂ. ಓ ಮನಸ್ಸೇ, ಜ್ಞಾಪಕಮಾಡು, ನನ್ನ ಕಾರ್ಯಗಳನ್ನು ಜ್ಞಾಪಕಮಾಡು; ಓ ಮನಸ್ಸೇ, ನೆನಪಿಡು, ನನ್ನ ಕಾರ್ಯಗಳನ್ನು ನೆನಪಿಸು.
tellmemore_en_adv:
This verse is a prayer uttered at the moment of death. The speaker is asking for their vital force (the life energy) to merge with the immortal Air, which represents the universal life force or cosmic spirit. This merging signifies the end of the individual life and the return to the universal source.

The speaker also accepts the fate of their physical body, acknowledging that it will be reduced to ashes, symbolizing the impermanence of the physical form.

The repetition of "Om" and the plea to the mind to remember all that has been done highlights the importance of reflecting on one's life and actions. "Om" is a sacred sound representing the ultimate reality, and invoking it signifies a connection with the divine.

The repeated call to remember suggests an earnest desire for the mind to recall all thoughts, actions, and experiences, recognizing their significance at the moment of transition from life to death. It is a reminder to the mind to acknowledge and integrate the entirety of one's life journey.

This verse is a poignant prayer at the time of death, seeking the merging of the individual life force with the cosmic spirit, acceptance of the body's return to ashes, and a reflective remembrance of all life's actions and experiences.
tellmemore_en_dva:
In Dvaita philosophy, these verses collectively address the immortality of God and the significance of divine blessings. The first part of the verse tackles a potential doubt about the mortality of God, explaining that while the physical body eventually turns to ashes, the Mukhyaprana (the chief vital force) within the body remains immortal because it is supported by God. This highlights that God's presence within the body does not perish with it, reaffirming His eternal and immortal nature.

The second part of the verse transitions into a prayer where the devotee praises God using the sacred syllable "Om," symbolizing the infinite and all-encompassing nature of God, who possesses countless qualities. The term "Krato" underscores God as the embodiment of knowledge (jnanasvarupa). The devotee seeks God’s blessings, asking Him to consider their deeds and grant His grace. This prayer emphasizes God's omniscience and constant presence, acknowledging that God’s knowledge is ever-present and does not require specific acts of remembering as humans do.

Together, these verses highlight the eternal nature of God within the perishable body and the devotee’s earnest plea for divine grace and blessings. They emphasize the immortality of the divine presence and the infinite attributes of God, reinforcing the core tenets of Dvaita philosophy which hold that God is both transcendent and immanent, ever-present, and the ultimate source of all qualities and knowledge.
tellmemore_en_vis: This verse addresses the transient nature of the physical body and the immortal nature of the soul. The pure soul, described as "Vayu," moves freely without a permanent abode and remains immortal despite the physical body's end. The phrase "Om Krato Smara" is a prayer to the divine, symbolized by "Kratu," to remember the soul's deeds. The repetition emphasizes the plea for the divine to acknowledge and remember the actions performed, underscoring the importance of one's deeds and the hope for divine grace and remembrance at the end of life.
tellmemore_hi_adv:
अधिदैवरूप अब मुझ मरनेवालेका वायु-प्राण अपने अध्यात्मपरिच्छेदको त्यागकर सर्वात्मक वायुरूप अमृत यानी सूत्रात्माको प्राप्त हो-
इस प्रकार इस वाक्य में 'प्रतिपद्यताम्' यह क्रियापद जोड़ लेना चाहिये । यहाँ यह समझना चाहिये किं ज्ञान और कर्मके संस्कारोंसे युक्त यह लिंग देह उत्क्रमण करे, क्योंकि [ इस श्रुतिसे ] मार्गकी याचना की गयी है । तथा अब यह शरीर अग्नि में होम कर दिये जानेपर भस्मशेष हो जाय । 'ॐ' ऐसा कहकर यहाँ उपासना- के अनुसार सत्यस्वरूप अग्निसंज्ञक ब्रह्म ही अभेदरूपसे कहा गया है, क्योंकि 'ॐ' उसका प्रतीक है । हे क्रतो ! - संकल्पात्मक मन ! तू इस समय जो मेरा स्मरणीय है उसका स्मरण कर; अब यह उसका समय उपस्थित हो गया है, अतः तू स्मरण कर । 'क्रतो स्मर कृतं स्मर' यहाँ [ 'स्मर' पदकी ] पुनरुक्ति आदर के लिये है ॥ १७ ॥

meaning_kn: ಓ ಅಗ್ನಿಯೇ, ಓ ದೇವರೇ, ನಮ್ಮ ಎಲ್ಲಾ ಕರ್ಮಗಳನ್ನು ತಿಳಿದುಕೊಂಡು, ನಮ್ಮ ಕರ್ಮಗಳ ಫಲವನ್ನು ಆನಂದಿಸಲು ಉತ್ತಮ ಮಾರ್ಗದಲ್ಲಿ ನಮ್ಮನ್ನು ನಡೆಸು. ನಮ್ಮೊಳಗಿನ ಮೋಸದ ಪಾಪವನ್ನು ತೊಡೆದುಹಾಕು. ಬಾಯಿಮಾತಿನ ಮೂಲಕ ನಾವು ನಿಮಗೆ ಅನೇಕ ಸಾಷ್ಟಾಂಗಗಳನ್ನು ಅರ್ಪಿಸುತ್ತೇವೆ.
tellmemore_en_adv:
In this verse, the seeker is addressing Agni, the fire god, who is also seen as a divine guide and purifier. The seeker requests Agni to lead them on the right path, which refers to the path of righteousness and truth, so that they can enjoy the fruits of their good deeds. The seeker acknowledges that Agni, being omniscient, knows all their actions and deeds.

The seeker also asks Agni to remove the deceitful sins from them, implying a plea for purification and forgiveness for any wrongdoings. This purification is essential for spiritual growth and progress.

Finally, the seeker expresses their devotion and respect by offering many words of salutation to Agni, acknowledging his divine role and seeking his blessings.
tellmemore_en_dva:
In Dvaita philosophy, this verse is a prayer to Agni, the deity who regulates both the body and the world. The devotee asks Agni to guide them on the right path towards prosperity, which in this context means spiritual liberation. The "right path" refers to the sacred journey, often symbolized by the path of light (archira) which leads to liberation and from which there is no return to the cycle of birth and death.

The prayer acknowledges God's omniscience, recognizing that He is aware of all the knowledge and actions of the devotee. The devotee requests God to remove the sins that bind them, which are obstacles on the path to liberation. By seeking the removal of these sins, the devotee aims to purify themselves and attain a state of spiritual freedom.

The verse concludes with the devotee offering profound salutations to God, expressing reverence and gratitude. This act of salutation is a recognition of God's supreme power and mercy.
tellmemore_en_vis: In this verse, Agni, symbolizing the Supreme Being, is invoked to guide the seeker towards material and spiritual wealth. Agni is acknowledged as omniscient and is beseeched to remove the sins that obstruct the path to liberation. The act of offering salutations signifies self-surrender and devotion to the Supreme. The wealth mentioned can be interpreted as both material prosperity and the ultimate wealth of attaining God. This verse encapsulates the essence of seeking divine guidance and purification from sins through devotion and prayer.

transliteration_en:
oṃ pūrṇamadaḥ pūrṇamidaṃ pūrṇātpūrṇamudacyate |

pūrṇasya pūrṇamādāya pūrṇamevāvaśiṣyate ||

oṃ śāntiḥ | śāntiḥ | śāntiḥ ||
meaning_en: That is complete; this is complete. From completeness emerges completeness. When completeness is taken from completeness, completeness still remains.
meaning_kn: ಅದು ಪೂರ್ಣವಾಗಿರುತ್ತದೆ, ಇದು ಪೂರ್ಣವಾಗಿರುತ್ತದೆ. ಪೂರ್ಣದಿಂದ ಪೂರ್ಣವು ಉದ್ಭವಿಸುತ್ತದೆ. ಪೂರ್ಣದಿಂದ ಪೂರ್ಣವನ್ನು ತೆಗೆದುಹಾಕಿದರೂ, ಉಳಿದುದೂ ಪೂರ್ಣವಾಗಿರುತ್ತದೆ. ಓಂ ಶಾಂತಿಃ ಶಾಂತಿಃ ಶಾಂತಿಃ॥
tellmemore_en_adv: This mantra reinforces the teachings of Advaita Vedanta by illustrating the infinite nature of both the supreme, unmanifested Brahman and the manifested, conditioned Brahman. It teaches that the universe, with all its diverse forms, emerges from the infinite Brahman, retaining its inherent infinitude. Through the knowledge of this true nature, one realizes that the conditioned Brahman (the manifested world) is essentially the same as the supreme Brahman. This realization dissolves the illusion of separateness, revealing the underlying unity of all existence. By understanding the infinite nature of both the source and the manifestation, one attains the vision of oneness, which is central to Advaita philosophy. The repeated invocation of peace signifies the ultimate tranquility and liberation that come with this profound realization.
tellmemore_en_dva: In Dvaita philosophy, which maintains a dualistic understanding of reality, this mantra underscores the distinct and complete nature of both the Supreme Being (Vishnu or Brahman) and the individual souls (jivas). According to Dvaita, "That" (Adah) refers to the Supreme Brahman, who is perfect and complete in itself. "This" (Idam) refers to the individual soul, which is also complete in its essence. The mantra illustrates that the Supreme Brahman is the source of all creation and remains unchanged and complete even after the creation process. The individual soul, though a part of creation, retains its distinct completeness derived from the Supreme. Despite the infinite process of creation, Brahman’s infinitude remains undiminished, highlighting the eternal, unchanging nature of God. The invocation of peace (Shanti) three times at the end signifies peace in the physical, mental, and spiritual realms, acknowledging the overarching completeness and tranquility of the divine.
tellmemore_en_vis:
The mantra "Om Purnamadah Purnamidam" emphasizes the completeness and fullness of both the ultimate reality (Brahman) and the manifested world. According to Vishishtadvaita, Brahman, with its infinite attributes and auspicious qualities, pervades everything, and this world is a manifestation of Brahman’s glory.

"That (other world) is full with the Veda" signifies that the spiritual realm is complete and perfect, filled with divine knowledge and truth as embodied in the Vedas. "This (world) is full with the Veda" implies that even the physical world is permeated with the divine knowledge and presence of Brahman.

The phrase "That which fills is more celebrated than the world that is filled" highlights the supremacy of Brahman, the source of all creation and existence. The manifested world, though full and complete in itself, derives its completeness from Brahman.

When the "Vyahrithi," or the agent of filling, is withdrawn from the world, what remains is the "Om Karatmaka Vastu," the ultimate reality characterized by Om, which is Brahman. This signifies the inherent and unchanging nature of Brahman, even when the dynamic aspects of creation and sustenance are set aside.

In essence, this mantra encapsulates the belief that Brahman is both immanent and transcendent, pervading all of existence while remaining beyond it. This fullness is the ultimate reality that remains constant, highlighting the non-dual yet multifaceted nature of Brahman as understood in Vishishtadvaita.
